DGACM.relevance_comment: Decides that annual reports of treaty bodies are not to contain separately published documents — this is a General Assembly decision affecting how treaty-body documentation is prepared and published. DGACM’s PPB shows it is responsible for parliamentary/documentation services (subprogramme 3; see 2.45–2.53, 2.46 strategy and 2.57 deliverables) and would be expected to implement changes to documentation production and publication formats arising from this decision.

Decides to establish a 10,700-word limit for each document produced by human rights treaty bodies (and recommends word limits for stakeholders). This creates a requirement that affects document processing and editorial control. DGACM’s documentation service (subprogramme 3: translation/editing/desktop publishing; see 2.46(a),(d), 2.50–2.56) implements and enforces such limits in the production workflow.

Decides to establish specific word limits for State party documentation (initial and subsequent reports, common core documents) and calls on treaty bodies to limit questions — this imposes constraints on the volume and format of documentation to be processed. DGACM’s documentation and publishing subprogrammes (subprogramme 3 and subprogramme 4; see 2.46, 2.59 and the discussion of timeliness/simultaneous issuance 2.48–2.56, 2.61–2.69) are the Secretariat units that would operationalize these limits in document intake, editing and issuance.

Decides to issue summary records in one working language and not to translate the pending backlog of summary records, while aiming to provide verbatim records in all official languages by alternative methods. This is a decision on the form and language of records and on issuance priorities. DGACM directly provides verbatim reporting, summary records, and publishing services (subprogramme 4 meetings and publishing services and subprogramme 3 documentation; see 2.59(a), 2.48–2.56, 2.61–2.69) and would be responsible for implementing these changes to record production and dissemination.

Decides that, at the request of any State party, a summary record of its meeting with a treaty body shall be translated into the UN official language used by that State party — this creates an operational requirement for translation and issuance on request. DGACM’s documentation services (subprogramme 3: translation/editing/précis-writing; see 2.46(a),(d) and 2.48–2.56) are the Secretariat function that would perform those translations and manage fulfilment of such requests.

Decides on the identification/allocation of meeting time to treaty bodies and explicitly requests the Secretary‑General to provide the corresponding financial and human resources. DGACM is the Secretariat entity responsible for planning and managing meetings and conference-servicing resources across duty stations (see 2.1(a),(c), 2.2, subprogramme 2 planning and coordination, and programme support 2.226–2.231) and would implement the allocation of meeting time and associated servicing resources.

Specifies the method for allocating weeks for review of State party reports (assumed review rates) as part of the meeting-time allocation (26(a)). This operational specification requires scheduling and provision of conference services. DGACM’s work on planning of intergovernmental meetings and tools (subprogramme 2: planning and coordination; see 2.33(a),(e), and references to e-deleGATE and scheduling in 2.20–2.30) is directly implicated in implementing this allocation.

Specifies additional allocation of meeting time for committees dealing with individual communications (method and time per communication). This places concrete scheduling and servicing requirements on the Secretariat. DGACM’s conference-servicing and meetings subprogrammes (subprogramme 4 meetings and publishing services and subprogramme 2 planning and coordination; see 2.59, 2.33 and performance measures for meetings and interpretation 2.63–2.66) would operationalize these allocations.

Establishes an additional margin (5% target increase, temporary 15% for 2015–2017) to prevent backlogs in meeting-time allocation — an explicit planning/resourcing target that the Secretariat must address. DGACM is responsible for surge planning, workforce/capacity management and temporary assistance to handle demand (see 2.7, 2.59(b), and programme support on capacity/planning 2.226–2.229), so it would implement measures to meet this target.

Calls for adequate allocation of financial and human resources to treaty bodies whose main mandated role is to carry out field visits. This is a resource direction to the Secretary‑General with operational implications for meeting/field support. DGACM’s mandate covers conference services, planning and coordination (including servicing of meetings and related logistics) across duty stations (see 2.1(a),(c), subprogramme 2 and programme support sections), and DGACM would be the implementing service for the Secretariat’s provision of meeting and documentation support related to such field activities, as applicable.

Decides that meeting-time allocations will be reviewed biennially on the basis of reporting over the previous four years and amended at the request of the Secretary‑General in line with budgetary procedures; also decides not to reduce prior permanent allocations. This establishes a process/timetable that the Secretariat must follow in scheduling and budgeting. DGACM is the Secretariat conference-management programme that prepares schedules, harmonized indicators and inputs for budget/resource allocation (see 2.33, 2.37–2.38 on reporting of KPIs and global harmonization, and programme support responsibilities 2.226–2.231) and would implement the review and any resulting scheduling/budget changes.

Requests the Secretary‑General to take into account the meeting time needed (per paragraphs 26 and 27) in his future biennial programme budget for the human rights treaty body system, including specific requirements for field visits. This is a direct instruction to budget for meeting-time needs. DGACM is the programme that is budgeted for and that provides the conference services and staffing that correspond to those budget lines (see resource and programme sections 2.190–2.197, and subprogramme resource explanations for meeting and documentation services 2.206–2.216), so DGACM would be responsible for delivering services funded under that budget.

Requests the Secretary‑General to ensure progressive implementation of relevant accessibility standards for the treaty body system and to provide reasonable accommodation for experts with disabilities to ensure full participation. DGACM’s PPB explicitly includes disability inclusion and accessibility measures for conference services (see 2.13 and specific references to accessibility services in duty-station subprogrammes 2.74–2.75, 2.101 and 2.141), and DGACM would be expected to implement accessible meeting arrangements and accommodations.

Decides to allocate a maximum of three official working languages for the work of the treaty bodies (with exceptional inclusion of a fourth) while preserving States’ rights to interact in any of the six official languages. This is a decision that directly affects language/interpretation coverage and costs. DGACM is the system-wide lead on multilingualism and is responsible for conference interpretation and multilingual documentation across duty stations (see 2.1(c), 2.3, subprogramme 4 interpretation/meetings services 2.59–2.66, and references to multilingualism coordination 2.9–2.11), and would operationalize and manage interpretation services consistent with this language allocation.
